title: 110_s2471
content: The "USERRA Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007" is the short title of this Act. It aims to reform the USERRA complaint process. The USERRA Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007 amends section 4322 of title 38, United States Code, to expedite the notification of rights to complainants and the investigation and resolution of complaints by the Secretary within 90 days. The USERRA Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007 requires the Secretary to complete investigations within 90 days of receiving a complaint. Referrals to the Attorney General or special counsel must be expedited within 15 days of receiving a request. Notification of representation by the Attorney General must be made within 45 days. The USERRA Enforcement Improvement Act of 2007 mandates that the Attorney General or Special Counsel must make a decision on representation within 45 days of receiving a referral. SEC. 3. EXPANSION OF REPORTING REQUIREMENTS FOR USERRA ENFORCEMENT. Modification of Annual Report by Secretary under title 38, United States Code includes reporting on cases reviewed by the Secretary of Defense through the National Committee for Employer Support of the Guard and Reserve, specifically focusing on disability-related issues. The modification of the annual report under title 38, United States Code includes reporting on cases involving disability-related issues, employment or reemployment of individuals with disabilities, and types of disabilities. Additionally, the Comptroller General of the United States is required to submit quarterly reports to Congress, the Secretary of Defense, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, the Attorney General, and the Special Counsel. The Comptroller General of the United States must submit quarterly reports to Congress, the Secretary of Defense, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, the Attorney General, and the Special Counsel. The report should include the number of cases where requirements were not met, referrals were not made on time, and referrals were not handled properly. The Comptroller General must submit quarterly reports to Congress, the Secretary of Defense, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, the Attorney General, and the Special Counsel regarding cases where requirements were not met, referrals were delayed, or mishandled. The Secretary is required to coordinate with other agencies to ensure uniform categorization of data in reports. Special Counsel, Secretary of Defense, Attorney General, and Special Counsel have electronic access to case files reviewed under this chapter. The amendments made by this section apply to reports required under section 4332 after the enactment of this Act.
